question_feedback.student_choice: OSPF converges faster and supports hierarchical network design through areas
question_feedback.correct_answer: OSPF converges faster and supports hierarchical network design through areas
question_feedback.explanation: OSPF converges faster than RIP due to its link-state algorithm and supports hierarchical design through areas, which improves scalability and reduces routing overhead in large networks.

question_feedback.student_choice: To serve as the central transit area that connects all other areas
question_feedback.correct_answer: To serve as the central transit area that connects all other areas
question_feedback.explanation: Area 0 serves as the backbone area that all other areas must connect to, either directly or through virtual links, ensuring proper inter-area routing and maintaining the hierarchical OSPF design.

question_feedback.student_choice: When it has been configured with the highest router priority, or highest router ID if priorities are equal
question_feedback.correct_answer: When it has been configured with the highest router priority, or highest router ID if priorities are equal
question_feedback.explanation: The DR is elected based on the highest router priority (configurable value), and if priorities are tied, then the highest router ID is used as the tiebreaker.

question_feedback.student_choice: OSPF maintains full topology awareness through link-state advertisements, enabling faster recalculation of paths
question_feedback.correct_answer: OSPF maintains full topology awareness through link-state advertisements, enabling faster recalculation of paths
question_feedback.explanation: OSPF's link-state algorithm maintains complete network topology information, allowing routers to immediately recalculate shortest paths when topology changes occur, resulting in faster convergence than distance-vector protocols.

question_feedback.student_choice: Discard the LSA as it contains outdated information
question_feedback.correct_answer: Discard the LSA as it contains outdated information
question_feedback.explanation: OSPF sequence numbers increase with each new LSA version. A lower sequence number indicates older, outdated information that should be discarded to maintain database consistency.
